content:

US MARKET WRAP - 26 October 2018: Stocks resume slide

* SNAP-SHOT: Equities down, Treasuries up, dollar down, crude up.

* REAR-VIEW: US Q3 GDP beat; Fed's Mester doesn’t see inflationary pressure, Fed’s Kaplan says Fed should shift towards neutral stance; China’s Xi to 'seriously consider' Japan’s Abe invitation to visit Japan; CBR unchanged; Italy continue defiance.

* NEXT WEEK: UK Autumn Budget; BoE, BoJ rate decision; US and Canadian labour data; US PCE, ISM mfg, construction spending, factory orders; Aussie Trade Balance; UK mfg and construction PMIs; Canadian trade balance.

 

* ITALY: EU's Moscovici said the EU is having constructive and "firm" talks with Italy but warned that if Italy does not resubmit its budget, the EU has options; the EU would look at other ways of Italy debt reduction, he said without providing details. The Bank of Italy, on request of ECB, has asked Italian banks for periodic updates on the state of its bond portfolios. Sources reported both the EU and Italian officials are closely watching the impact of the increasing Bund/BTP spreads on domestic banks (the Bank of Italy will soon publish an impact assessment). Italy's Deputy PM Di Maio said ECB's Draghi’s comments at his post-ECB meeting press conference were a ‘poisoning climate’ for Italy after Draghi said he sees only a limited spill over effect, while urging Italy to fully adhere to Eurozone budget rules is needed in high debt countries. He was also unconcerned about the S&P rating decision on the country, due today after the US closing bell. Also, League Lawmaker Borghi has suggested that any action is likely to be moderate.

* FED: Fed's Mester (hawk, voter) said her long run federal fund's rate forecast was 3.00%; she noted wages are rising but are not yet stoking inflationary pressure. Fed's Kaplan (neutral, non-voter) said the Fed should gradually and patiently move towards a neutral stance.

* ECB: Coeure (dovish) said significant monetary policy stimulus is still needed to support the further build-up of domestic price pressures and headline inflation developments over the medium term; he explained this support will continue to be provided by the net asset purchases until the end of the year, by the sizeable stock of acquired assets and the associated reinvestments, and by our enhanced forward guidance on the key ECB interest rates. He reiterated that the ECB expects its key policy rates to remain at their present levels at least through the summer of 2019.

 * TRADE: The Canadian Ambassador to Washington said the US and Canada will resolve issues regarding metals tariffs "sooner rather than later".

* GEOPOLITICS: A spokesperson reported Chinese President Xi to 'seriously consider' Japanese PM Abe invitation to visit Japan. Elsewhere, White House Adviser Bolton said to be unaware 'at this point' of plans for US sanctions on Russian sovereign debt.

* ADVANCED US GDP for Q3 came in at 3.5%, higher than the expected 3.3%; the PCE Price Index increased 1.6%, missing expectations for 2.0%. Analysts at Wells Fargo pointed out that Q3 overall growth was supported by real personal consumption expenditures, which were up 4%, and partially boosted by real disposable income. On the flip side, fixed investment spending and construction declined, with the latter indicating a contraction in the housing market. Looking ahead, Wells Fargo expects growth to slow a tad in the quarters ahead, although noting ‘with the labour market more or less at “full employment” and with some measures of inflation trending higher, we look for the Federal Reserve to continue raising rates at a gradual pace for the next year or so”.

* UNI OF MICHIGAN SENTIMENT INDEX (Final) fell 1.5 points in October posting at 98.6, a tab below the 99.0 consensus though overall remaining at an elevated level. Analysts at Wells Fargo argue the recent stock market volatility as well as higher gasoline prices are two factors placing pressure on sentiment.

* SPX -1.74% at 2658, NDX -2.34% at 6852, DJI -1.20% at 24686. SECTORS: Energy -0.79%, Materials -0.65%, Industrials -0.98%, Cons Discretionary -3.55%, Cons Staples -1.69%, Healthcare -1.08%, Financials -1.39%, Tech -1.87%, Telecoms -2.40%, Utilities -1.70%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Phillips 66 (PSX) was a top mover after beating estimates for both EPS and revenue, so did Intel (INTC) which also raised its full year guidance. Tesla (TSLA) continued on from yesterday’s gains after its strong earnings, but news broke that the automakers’ Model 3 weekly production slightly down, overall quarterly production close to 25,000 cars, according to Electrek; additionally, the criminal investigation examining if Model 3 production was misstated intensified in recent weeks, sources reported. Expedia (EXPE) traded higher after beating EPS estimates. Cabot Oil & Gas (COG) another top mover following a strong beat on revenue estimates. Amazon (AMZN) weighed down the consumer discretionary sector after missing revenue estimates and providing Q4 revenue guidance below expectations. Western Digital (WDC) cliff-dived following mentioning a decline in flash-memory pricing. Digital Realty Trust (DLR) also a bottom mover after reporting less than expected FFO. Advanced Micron Devices (AMD) continued its losses from yesterday.

* WTI (Z8) SETTLES USD 0.26 HIGHER AT USD 67.59/BBL, BRENT (Z8) SETTLES USD 0.73 HIGHER AT USD 77.62/BBL. For much of the day, crude was tracking overall risk sentiment, sliding as equities were under pressure and the dollar index rose to multi-month highs. “The market also seems to be focussing more on Thursday’s OPEC assessment that inventories have recently increased rather than the likelihood that they may do something about it,” analysts at Citi said. Elsewhere, Iraq will stop trucking Kirkuk crude to Iran in November in compliance with us sanctions, Sources reported. And in Texas, Phillips 66 (PSX) is planning to add 2.2mln BPD of crude oil storage at the Beaumont refinery.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) SETTLE 16 TICKS HIGHER AT 119-01.

* WEEKLY FX WRAP - DXY: This week was near enough one-way traffic for the DXY with the index moving from lows of 95.50 seen earlier in the week before breaching 96.50 to the upside during Thursday’s trade after risk-aversion in equity markets prompted a FTQ into the greenback. The index was also aided by the advanced reading of US GDP on Friday which printed at 3.5% vs. Exp. 3.3%, thus signalling best back-to-back quarters since 2014. Credit Agricole note that recent USD performance suggests month-end portfolio-rebalancing flows are likely to prompt strong USD buying across the board.

* EUR: In-fitting with the theme of USD strength, EUR/USD continued to head south throughout the week with the pair conceding both the 1.15 and 1.14 handles to reach levels not seen since mid-August. This week’s ECB meeting provided little in the way of fireworks on the policy front with Draghi refraining from providing any greater clarity on what lies ahead for the Bank’s normalisation process. Draghi maintained the Bank’s assessment that risks to the Eurozone economy remain broadly balanced whilst downplaying the recent weakening in momentum. However, this was not enough to stop the rot for the shared currency with Italian political risk an ever-looming threat alongside the rampant USD.

* GBP: An equally uninspiring week was seen for GBP with the 1.30+ levels seen at the start of the week firmly in the rear-view mirror. Again, traction in the USD was arguably the main guiding force for Cable but political events in the UK remain a great cause of concern for investors. Most notably, reports towards the end of the week appear to signal that intra-cabinet discussions with Mrs May’s team have ground to a halt ahead of the (as of yet unconfirmed) November EU leaders’ summit and as such, a test of YTD lows around 1.2660 cannot be ruled out.

*AUD, CNY: In the Asia-Pac region, the PBoC garnered a significant amount of market attention after the Bank opted to set the fix beyond 6.9500 for the first time since early January 2017. This prompted selling in some of its regional high-beta peers with AUD/USD knocked towards Feb 2016 lows of 0.7021 before stopping shy of 0.7000 where there were said to be large barriers. A PBoC Vice Governor later stated that the central bank will take necessary and target measures to deal with those who short the CNY which subsequently prompted some CNY buying but wasn’t enough to lend a helping hand to AUD or NZD. AUD remains the worst performing G10 currency over the past 3 months with Westpac highlighting local politics as an ongoing issue for the currency and flag week’s CPI release as the next test for market sentiment with the Bank expecting a ‘soft income’.

* EMs: Elsewhere, this week’s other central bank releases saw the Norges, CBRT and CBR all stand pat on rates. In terms of the specifics of each decision, the NB refrained from taking action in their ‘in-between’ meeting and continued to flag the likelihood of a Q1 2019 hike after the Bank’s maintained the economic assessment released in September; NOK subsequently unreactive. Over in Turkey, the CBRT opted to stand pat on rates after their mammoth hike last time around. In the accompanying statement, the Bank vowed to deliver further monetary tightening if needed, will continue to use all available instruments in pursuit of price stability. This saw the TRY gain ground against the USD with CBRT suggesting that their rate-hike cycle might still have some room to run. Finally, the CBR maintained rates at 7.5% after the unexpectedly raising rates by 25bps at its previous policy meeting. The Bank noted that they will consider the need for additional rate hikes, taking into account inflation and economic dynamics.

* CBR REVIEW: The Central Bank of Russia maintained its benchmark rate at 7.5%, in line with the analyst consensus; the CBR explained that CPI is on track to rise from 3.5% YY towards 3.8% to 4.2% band by the end-2018, rising to 5.0% to 5.5% by the end of next year, as the RUB depreciation impact, as well as the upcoming VAT tax hike filters through. The central bank maintained its growth view. Looking ahead, analysts at ING expect the CBR to be between a hold and a hike: “there was no change in the assessment of the inflationary risks,” ING says “which highlights the uncertainties faced by the monetary authorities with the near-to-mid-term,” and ING “expects the key rate to remain unchanged until the end of the year under the assumption that CPI will stay within the CBR guidelines.” With that said, ING acknowledges that risks to its view on CPI and the key rate are tilted towards the upside. ING explains that the most obvious risk, as stated by the CBR, includes continued capital outflows from EMs, as well as Russia-specific foreign policy risks. “the less obvious risk – the one the CBR didn’t mention – is the growing uncertainty regarding the local gasoline price growth,” ING says, noting local media reports which have suggested that the upcoming increase in excise duties and the upcoming tax changes in the oil industry may trigger an increase in local prices by around 10%, which could push headline CPI up by 0.4ppts. “However, the secondary effects could amplify the potential deterioration in the inflationary trend,” ING writes, “for now, it remains unclear whether the government will prevent this growth via budgetary or other means.”

* NEXT WEEK: Monday: UK Autumn Budget, US PCE Tuesday: BoJ Interest Rate Decision, Eurozone GDP Wednesday: Chinese PMIs, BoJ Outlook Report, Australian CPI, US Chicago PMI, Canadian GDP & PPI, Eurozone CPI & Unemployment Thursday: BoE Interest Rate Decision, Minutes & QIR, Caixin Mfg PMI, Australian Trade Balance, UK Mfg PMI, US ISM Mfg PMI & Construction Spending Friday: Australian PPI, UK Construction PMI, US & Canadian Labour Market report, Canadian Trade Balance, US Factory Orders. CREDIT RATINGS: Potential credit rating agency actions after the bell on Friday include: S&P on Italy (BBB, stable); S&P on UK (AA, negative), Fitch on UK (AA, negative); S&P on Germany (AAA, stable); Moody's on France (Aa2, positive)
content: RBC on Italian rating review: "S&P currently have Italy at BBB with a stable outlook but warned at their previous review in April of risks to the rating ‘if the government strayed from the previous budget path or undid previous reforms’. As the coalition government’s budget contains both, it looks highly unlikely to us that S&P will retain their rating and outlook at the current level. At the end of August, Fitch cut the outlook on its BBB rating to negative from stable while late last week Moody’s cut Italy’s rating to Baa3 from Baa2 previously though with a stable outlook and a similar move from S&P, at the least, looks likely."

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 26th October 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European stocks are negative across the board in a continuation of the sell-off experienced in Asia overnight and on Wall St. yesterday; Pre-market: Amazon -10.2%. Alphabet -5.9%
  • DXY trades marginally firmer, extending on gains seen yesterday which pushed the index back above 96.50
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US GDP, PCE Prices, Baker Hughes, S&P on Italy, Fed’s Bostic, ECB’s Draghi, Coeure

ASIA

Asian stocks were broadly negative as early attempts to nurse the prior day’s sell-off and replicate the rebound seen on Wall St, were thwarted amid Amazon revenue disappointment which weighed across equity futures. ASX 200 (Unch) traded choppy but managed to pare back losses towards the end of the session and Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) failed to hold on to opening gains as the Japanese benchmark gradually deteriorated with earnings dominating news flow. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) and Hang Seng (-1.1%) both conformed to downbeat tone, although the mainland briefly outperformed after this week’s substantial liquidity injection and with China also said to be considering additional tax and fee reductions including a VAT adjustment. Finally, 10yr JGBs eventually traded higher amid the widespread risk-averse tone in the region and with BoJ’s present in the market for JPY 1.1tln in 1yr-10yr JGBs.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net weekly injection of CNY 460bln vs. Prev. CNY 30bln injection W/W. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9510 (Prev. 6.9409)

China views USD/CNY 7.00 as an 'important' level and would likely intervene at that stage to prevent a rapid decline, according to sources. (Newswires)

PBoC Vice Governor says the central bank will take necessary and target measures to deal with those who short the yuan. (Newswires)

BoJ officials are said not to want sharp moves in 10yr yields, while reports noted some at the BoJ are said to see a 10yr yield limit of over 0.2%. (Newswires)

Japanese Tokyo CPI (Oct) Y/Y 1.5% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.3%). (Newswires)
Japanese Tokyo CPI Ex. Fresh Food (Oct) Y/Y 1.0% vs. Exp. 1.0% (Prev. 1.0%)
Japanese Tokyo CPI Ex. Fresh Food & Energy (Oct) Y/Y 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. 0.7%)

EU

Bank of Italy, on request of ECB, has asked Italian banks for periodic update on their state bond portfolios. (Newswires)

EU Financial Affairs Commissioner Moscovici says they are having constructive and "firm" talks regarding the Italian situation, while he added that if Italy does not resubmit budget, the EU has options. Furthermore, he stated that the EU would look at other ways of Italy debt reduction. (Newswires)

EU and Italian officials are closely watching the impact of the increasing IT/GE 10yr spread on domestic Italian lenders, according to sources. (Newswires)

ECB Survey of Professional Forecasters downgraded 2018 GDP to 2.0% (Prev. 2.2%), 2019 to 1.8% (Prev. 1.9%) and maintained 2020 at 1.6%. The survey also showed the CPI forecast maintained at 1.7% for 2018, 2019, and 2020. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

Fed's Mester (Voter, Hawk) said US policy remains accommodative and need to raise rates into neutral territory. Mester also said she expects further gradual US rate hikes, while she added the Fed is nearing end of extraordinary policy and is close to normal. (Newswires)

ECB's Villeroy said ECB is increasingly confident in the inflation path and that the question of TLROs will need to be considered, while there were separate source reports that the ECB is looking to distribute large PSPP reinvestments over a longer period from next year. (Newswires)

Norges Bank Governor Olsen said the key policy rate will remain low and moderate for a long time and emphasised that the increase will be gradual. He also stated that underlying inflation is approaching the NB’s target. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European stocks are negative across the board in a continuation of the sell-off experienced in Asia overnight. Almost 80% of the Stoxx 600 companies are in the red, while Eurostoxx 50 (-2.0%) flirts around levels last seen in November 2016, with the biggest losers consisting of German and French heavyweights such as Deutsche Bank (-4.5%), Airbus (-3.9%) and Total (-3.5%)

France’s CAC 40 (-2.3%) underperforms its peers with the index pressured by Valeo (-21.1%) after the company cut revenue guidance for FY 18. Over in Germany, the DAX (-2.0%) is weighed on by index heavyweight BASF (-2.2%) after the company forecasts adjusted EBIT guidance to the lower end of their previously guided range, while Covestro (-5.4%) rests at the foot of the index amid a downgrade at Berenberg. Sectors are experiencing broad-based losses with energy names pressured by price action in the complex and IT names uninspired following a revenue-miss reported by Alphabet (-5.9% pre-market).

On the flip side, gainers in the Stoxx 600 are fuelled by earnings with Neste (+7.0%), Fingerprint Cards (+7.0%) and Banco de Sabadell (+4.5%) all higher following their numbers.

FX

The DXY trades marginally firmer, extending on gains seen yesterday which pushed the index back above 96.50. Subsequently, EUR/USD remains on a 1.13 handle and below support at 1.1358 with relatively upbeat tones from Draghi yesterday unable to support the multi-bloc currency. Focus today for the EUR (absent of any negative Italian headlines), could well fall upon the slew of option activity with a slew of option expiries due to roll-off at the NY cut; 1.1350 (1.3bln), 1.1375 (1.3bln), 1.1400 (918mln), 1.1450-55 (1.1mln). From a tech perspective, if EUR/USD makes a break of 1.1350 to the downside, focus will turn to the August 16th low at 1.1336.

GBP/USD has breached yesterday’s lows in recent trade alongside the aforementioned USD strength, with the latest Brexit-related commentary also bringing markets back to reality. Sources suggest that Brexit talks are on hold as UK PM May's team cannot agree a way forward on how to proceed with negotiations and as such Cable is back below 1.2800. A sustained break below this level could open a test of YTD lows around 1.2660, particularly so, with November’s emergency EU leaders summit far from confirmed.

Given the current risk environment (post-disappointing after-market large cap US earnings; inc Amazon and Alphabet), JPY is bucking the trend vs. the USD and is currently sitting just below 112.00 where there were said to be strong bids from Japanese importers. If the US opts to accelerate losses in US equities, this could drag the pair back towards October lows around 111.62; notable options today for USD/JPY includes 111.50 (565mln), 112.00-20 (611mln), 112.50 (526mln), 113.00 (1.2bln).

Once again, focus during Asia-Pac trade continued to focus on the CNY after the PBoC opted to set the fix beyond 6.9500 for the first time since early January 2017. This subsequently prompted selling in high-beta currencies with AUD and NZD feeling the brunt with AUD/USD knocked below Feb 2016 lows of 0.7023. However, prices eventually bottomed out amid comments from the PBoC Vice Governor said the central bank will take necessary and target measures to deal with those who short the CNY; USD/CNY subsequently retreated from 6.9500 to 6.9350.

Looking ahead, EM focus could be guided by events in Russia with the CBR due to come to market with their latest policy announcement. After the CBR unexpectedly raised rates by 25bps at its previous policy meeting, the consensus expects the central bank to maintain its one-week auction rate at 7.50%. Analysts at Barclays suggest that September's rate hike has probably done enough to contain the pressure in the RUB and given the still below target inflation and a weak economy.

COMMODITIES

Gold is on target to notch a fourth week in the green, marking the yellow metal’s longest set of weekly gains since January; spurred on by ongoing economic constraints and concern over US corporate earnings. Prices continue to extend north of USD 1230/oz, while printing fresh session highs. Copper prices have retreated overnight as the red metal was weighed on by the market’s negative tone, eroding Thursday’s gains from a drop-in inventory.

WTI and Brent are both extending losses in excess of a percent with the latter losing the USD 76.00/bbl level, in-fitting with the risk sentiment and signs that global trade is slowing with both container and bulk freight rates dropping, while yesterday’s comments of an upcoming oversupply by Saudi Arabia’s OPEC governor Al-Aama also weighing on prices. Additionally, markets are waiting for today’s Baker Hughes rig count which showed an increase of four operational oil rigs last week.

The German government has reportedly released emergency oil reserves. (WiWo)

FIXED INCOME

After initially spiking higher to 160.56 at the Eurex open, Bunds staged a mild retracement before moving higher once again. Prices remain supported (+44 ticks) by the broader risk environment with events post-US close yesterday souring sentiment in the market. Investors await the lead from the US after market-darlings Amazon and Alphabet posted disappointing earnings metrics. Should sentiment on Wall St begin to waiver further, analysts have suggested a potential test of early September highs at 160.98 could be on the cards before an eventual play on 161.00. In the periphery, Italian paper trades a touch softer with losses of circa 26 ticks with markets mindful of rating agency action after-market from S&P, ahead of which, Italian League Lawmaker Borghi has suggested that any action is likely to be moderate. Perhaps more concerning for Italy was earlier cryptic comments from EU’s Moscovici who warned that, if Italy does not resubmit budget, the EU has options. Elsewhere, Gilts remain elevated with lingering Brexit concerns leading prices towards early September highs of 122.75, whilst USTs remain firmer amid the broader risk environment after topping resistance seen at 118.27+; 119.00 is the next target (last seen in late Sep).

BofAML weekly flow report: a week of equity inflows
content:
Summary:

  • Equities: large inflows $8.5bn ($16.1bn ETF inflows, $7.6bn mutual fund outflows)
  • Bonds: 5th week of outflows ($7.2bn)
  • Precious metals: small inflows ($0.2bn)

Fixed Income Flows:

  • More huge IG bond fund outflows ($3.1bn)
  • Large HY bond outflows ($2.9bn)
  • Modest EM debt outflows ($1.1bn)
  • 6th week of muni fund outflows ($0.3bn)
  • Small Govt/Tsy inflows ($0.2bn)
  • 7th week of TIPS outflows ($0.1bn)
  • Bank loan fund inflows 33 of past 35 weeks ($0.1bn)

Equity Flows:

  • US: small inflows ($1.8bn)
  • Japan: more large inflows ($5.3bn)
  • Europe: outflows 32 of past 33 weeks ($0.1bn)
  • EM: biggest inflows in 7 months ($2.6n)
  • By style: inflows to US large cap ($4.7bn), US small cap ($0.1bn); outflows US growth ($0.8bn), US value ($1.0bn)
  • By sector: inflows tech ($0.1bn); outflows utilities ($8mn), healthcare ($0.2bn), energy ($0.3bn), materials ($0.4bn), real estate ($0.5bn), consumer ($0.6bn), financials ($1.5bn)

Talking Points

  • Weekly flows: $7.2bn redemptions from bonds, $8.5bn inflows to equities.
  • Move along: biggest EM inflows ($2.6bn) in 7 months & 2nd week of chunky Japan flows ($5.3bn) despite 4% global equity sell-off this week.
  • Risk-off in Credit: big $3.1bn IG bond outflows…IG outflows past 8 weeks record $25.2bn.
  • QT pain for Financials: further evidence of GT10 >3% hurting growth…biggest 4 week financials outflows (-$5.3bn) on record.
  • Technical "buy": BofAML Global Breadth Rule ringing "buy" as 42 of 45 equity indexes now oversold…most since Jan'16.
  • The Big Low…not yet: BofAML Bull & Bear Indicator @ 3.0 yet to breach excessively bearish level of <2.0 needed for major "buy" signal…need to see unwind of CTFC crude oil longs, EM fund outflows >$30bn & HY outflows >$15bn next 4 weeks for meaningful entry point; $2.6bn into EM, $0.3bn energy & $2.9 HY outflows this week not enough…until then only "dead cat bounces"
  • Private clients: Wall St. fear yet to grip Main St.; BofAML's Private Client ($2.3 trillion AUM) ETF holdings show GWIM buying equities, selling bonds…not following playbook from four weeks preceding prior market panics (Feb'16, Oct'11, Mar'09).

PRIMER: CBR Rate Decision to be published at 1130 BST on Friday 26 October 2018
content: After the CBR unexpectedly raised rates by 25bps at its previous policy meeting, the consensus expects the central bank to maintain its one week auction rate at 7.50%. Analysts at Barclays suggest that September's rate hike has probably done enough to contain the pressure in the RUB and given the still below target inflation and a weak economy. Accordingly, the central bank is also seen leaving its FX purchase on pause until the end of the year. Since the previous meeting, the RUB has strengthened by around 7% against the USD; HSBC notes that "the suspension of FX purchases effectively removes almost USD 30bln of potential demand for hard currency in September-December, allowing the RUB to benefit from high oil prices," and additionally, "the policy move has stemmed capital outflows, with non-residents' OFZ selling easing to RUB 45bln in September after spiking to almost RUB 100bln the preceding month." Inflation is also now in line with the central bank's end-2018 forecast of between 3.8% and 4.2% YY. And additionally, the geopolitical situation may also warrant caution. HSBC explains that "The 90-day deadline for Russia to avoid possible further sanctions relating to the Skripal case expires 10 days after the MPC, suggesting policymakers might wait to see if any fresh action is taken," and also that the US' Congress will not have an opportunity to consider two additional legislative initiatives on Russian sanctions prior to mid-term elections on 6 November.

subject: RANsquawk EU Mid Session - 26th October 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

EU MID-SESSION UPDATE: European equities falter as the risk tone turns to FTQ

EQUITIES

European stocks are negative across the board in a continuation of the sell-off experienced in Asia overnight and on Wall St. yesterday. Almost 80% of the Stoxx 600 companies are in the red, while Eurostoxx 50 (-1.6%) flirts around levels last seen in November 2016, with the biggest losers consisting of German and French heavyweights such as Deutsche Bank (-3.4%), Airbus (-3.0%) and BASF (-3%).

France’s CAC 40 (-2.1%) underperforms its peers with the index pressured by Valeo (-19.3%) after the company cut revenue guidance for FY 18. Over in Germany, the DAX (-1.9%) is weighed on by index heavyweight BASF (-3.0%) after the company forecasts adjusted EBIT guidance to the lower end of their previously guided range, while Covestro (-5.7%) rests at the foot of the index amid a downgrade at Berenberg. Sectors are experiencing broad-based losses with energy names pressured by price action in the complex and IT names uninspired following a revenue-miss reported by Alphabet (-5.0% pre-market).

On the flip side, gainers in the Stoxx 600 are fuelled by earnings with Neste (+9.0%), Fingerprint Cards (+7.4%) and Banco de Sabadell (+5.2%) all higher following their numbers

FX

The DXY trades relatively unchanged thus far, managing to hold onto gains seen yesterday which pushed the index back above 96.50. Subsequently, EUR/USD remains on a 1.13 handle after finding support at 1.1358 with relatively upbeat tones from Draghi yesterday unable to support the multi-bloc currency. Focus today for the EUR (absent of any negative Italian headlines), could well fall upon the slew of option activity with a slew of option expiries due to roll-off at the NY cut; 1.1350 (1.3bln), 1.1375 (1.3bln), 1.1400 (918mln), 1.1450-55 (1.1mln). From a tech perspective, if EUR/USD makes a break of 1.1350 to the downside, focus will turn to the August 16th low at 1.1336. 

GBP trades relatively flat and in close proximity to yesterday’s lows brought about by the aforementioned USD strength, with the latest Brexit-related commentary also bringing markets back to reality. Sources suggest that Brexit talks are on hold as UK PM May's team cannot agree a way forward on how to proceed with negotiations and as such Cable is currently treading water above 1.2800. A sustained break below this level could open a test of YTD lows around 1.2660, particularly so, with November’s emergency EU leaders summit far from confirmed. 

Given the current risk environment (post-disappointing after-market large cap US earnings; inc Amazon and Alphabet), JPY is bucking the trend vs. the USD and is currently sitting just below 112.00 where there were said to be strong bids from Japanese importers. If the US opts to accelerate losses in US equities, this could drag the pair back towards October lows around 111.62; notable options today for USD/JPY includes 111.50 (565mln), 112.00-20 (611mln), 112.50 (526mln), 113.00 (1.2bln).

Once again, focus during Asia-Pac trade continued to focus on the CNY after the PBoC opted to set the fix beyond 6.9500 for the first time since early January 2017. This subsequently prompted selling in high-beta currencies with AUD and NZD feeling the brunt with AUD/USD knocked down to Feb 2016 lows at 0.7023. However, prices eventually bottomed out amid comments from the PBoC Vice Governor said the central bank will take necessary and target measures to deal with those who short the CNY; USD/CNY subsequently retreated from 6.9500 to 6.9350. 

Looking ahead, EM focus could be guided by events in Russia with the CBR due to come to market with their latest policy announcement. After the CBR unexpectedly raised rates by 25bps at its previous policy meeting, the consensus expects the central bank to maintain its one week auction rate at 7.50%. Analysts at Barclays suggest that September's rate hike has probably done enough to contain the pressure in the RUB and given the still below target inflation and a weak economy.

FIXED INCOME

After initially spiking higher to 160.56 at the Eurex open, Bunds staged a mild retracement before moving higher once again. Prices remain supported (+39 ticks) by the broader risk environment with events post-US close yesterday souring sentiment in the market. Investors await the lead from the US after market-darlings Amazon and Alphabet posted disappointing earnings metrics. Should sentiment on Wall St begin to waiver further, analysts have suggested a potential test of early September highs at 160.98 could be on the cards before an eventual play on 161.00. In the periphery, Italian paper trades a touch softer with losses of circa 18 ticks with markets mindful of rating agency action after-market from S&P, ahead of which, Italian League Lawmaker Borghi has suggested that any action is likely to be moderate. Perhaps more concerning for Italy was earlier cryptic comments from EU’s Moscovici who warned that, if Italy does not resubmit budget, the EU has options. Elsewhere, Gilts remain elevated with lingering Brexit concerns leading prices towards early September highs of 122.75, whilst USTs remain firmer amid the broader risk environment after topping resistance seen at 118.27+; 119.00 is the next target (last seen in late Sep).

COMMODITIES

Gold is on target to notch a fourth week in the green, marking the yellow metal’s longest set of weekly gains since January; spurred on by ongoing economic constraints and concern over US corporate earnings. Prices continue to extend north of USD 1230/oz, while printing fresh session highs. Copper prices have retreated overnight as the red metal was weighed on by the market’s negative tone, eroding Thursday’s gains from a drop-in inventory.

WTI and Brent are both in the red in-fitting with the risk sentiment and signs that global trade is slowing with both container and bulk freight rates dropping, while yesterday’s comments of an upcoming oversupply by Saudi Arabia’s OPEC governor Al-Aama also weighing on prices. Additionally, markets are waiting for today’s Baker Hughes rig count which showed an increase of four operational oil rigs last week.

Brexit talks are on hold as UK PM May's team cannot agree a way forward on how to proceed with negotiations, according to sources. As such, it is almost certain that there will be no new proposals before Monday’s budget statement. (Newswires)  

UK’s NIESR states that a no deal Brexit could reduce UK growth by 1.6 points in 2019. (Newswires)

ECB's Villeroy said ECB is increasingly confident in the inflation path and that the question of TLROs will need to be considered, while there were separate source reports that the ECB is looking to distribute large PSPP reinvestments over a longer period from next year. (Newswires)

Italy's Economy Minister Tria said budget plan is not a threat to the Eurozone or to the stability of our European partners and that there is no way Italy wants to leave the euro, while Italy's EU Minister Savona commented that if Italian/German bond yields rises and nobody intervenes then banks could be put in a difficult situation. (Newswires)


FX

FX markets initially struggled for direction amid a lack of key data releases which kept the DXY near the prior day’s best levels, while its major counterparts were subdued with EUR/USD at the 1.1300 handle and in which GBP/USD languished near 1.2800 amid continued Brexit blues with talks said to be on hold due to disagreement within UK PM May's team. Elsewhere, antipodeans were pressured following a weaker reference rate by the PBoC which set the fix beyond 6.9500 for the first time since early January 2017, and with the selling in high-beta currencies exacerbated as the risk tone further deteriorated which subsequently spurred flows into the JPY.

COMMODITIES

Commodities traded subdued with WTI crude futures back below the USD 67.00/bbl, as the rebound in oil prices and risk sentiment stalled overnight. Elsewhere, the negative tone across Asia bourses also weighed on copper prices, while gold was kept range-bound with safe-haven demand for the precious metal counterbalanced as the greenback remained firm.
 

US

Treasuries remained marginally lower on Thursday, moving in opposite direction to equities which strongly rebounded from yesterday’s sell-off. The complex shrugged off solid US data including durables goods and pending home sales; most of the action was in the belly of the curve were yields were higher by just over 1bps at settlement. 2s5s were wider by c.1bps whilst 5s30s were narrower by c.2bps. The US Treasury sold USD 31bln of 7-year notes, tailing by 0.5bps; demand for the auction was soft with the bid-to-cover coming in at 2.39x, slightly below recent averages but highest since January. Directs took a portion less than half recent averages and the lowest since 2011 and indirects were awarded the biggest slice of the auction together securing ~70%; dealers were left with the remaining ~30%, slightly above recent averages. US T-note futures (Z8) settled down 3 ticks at 118-17.

Fed Vice Chair Clarida (Voter) said some further rate hikes are warranted, while he sees current policy as accommodative and higher rates will be appropriate. (Newswires)

Fed's Mester (Voter, Hawk) said US policy remains accommodative and need to raise rates into neutral territory. Mester also said she expects further gradual US rate hikes, while she added the Fed is nearing end of extraordinary policy and is close to normal. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Attempts for a global stock recovery was thwarted by Amazon revenue disappointment
content: Asian stocks were negative as early attempts to nurse the prior day’s sell-off and replicate the rebound seen on Wall St, were thwarted amid Amazon revenue disappointment which weighed across equity futures. ASX 200 (-0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) failed to hold on to opening gains as the initial tech-led bounce back in Australia was overshadowed by weakness in gold and energy-related stocks, while the Japanese benchmark gradually deteriorated with earnings dominating news flow. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-0.6%) and Hang Seng (-1.5%) both conformed to downbeat tone, although the mainland briefly outperformed after this week’s substantial liquidity injection and with China also said to be considering additional tax and fee reductions including a VAT adjustment. Finally, 10yr JGBs eventually traded higher amid the widespread risk-averse tone in the region and with BoJ’s present in the market for JPY 1.1tln in 1yr-10yr JGBs.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Amazon revenue disappointment thwarts global stock recovery
content:
Asia stocks are cautious as attempts by the regional bourses to nurse the prior day’s sell-off and replicate the rebound on Wall St were thwarted by Amazon revenue disappointment which weighed on equity futures after-hours. ASX 200 (-0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) are choppy as the initial tech-led bounce back in Australia was limited by weakness in gold and energy-related stocks, while the Japanese benchmark is also indecisive with earnings dominating news flow. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) and Hang Seng (-0.6%) are cautious but with mild outperformance in the mainland after this week’s substantial liquidity injection and with China also said to be considering additional tax and fee reductions including a VAT adjustment.

FX markets have struggled for direction overnight amid a lack of key data releases or catalysts. This has kept the DXY near the prior day’s best levels, while its major counterparts are subdued with EUR/USD at the 1.1300 handle and with GBP/USD nearing 1.2800 to the downside amid continued Brexit blues with talks said to be on hold due to disagreement within UK PM May's team. Elsewhere, antipodeans are lower following a weaker reference rate by the PBoC which set the fix to beyond 6.9500 for the first time since early January 2017, while USD/JPY mirrored the indecisive risk tone.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower with prices failing to benefit despite the cautious risk tone in the region and BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY 1.1tln in 1yr-10yr JGBs.
